required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intrapartum Glucose Management Among Women With Gestational Diabetes Mellitus
clinical_study.official_title: Intrapartum Glucose Management Among Women With Gestational Diabetes Mellitus and Its Impact on Neonatal Blood Glucose Levels

lead_sponsor.agency: Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island

clinical_study.source: Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island

brief_summary.textblock: Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) is one of the most common medical complications of pregnancy. Neonatal hypoglycemia is a common and well described complication for infants born to mothers with GDM and diabetes mellitus (DM) and studies have linked intrapartum maternal glucose levels with neonatal hypoglycemia. While guidelines exist to guide practitioners in how to best manage intrapartum maternal glucose levels among Type I and and Type II DM, there is a paucity of data guiding practitioners in the intrapartum management of blood glucose levels for women with GDM, particularly those treated with insulin antepartum. The goal of this project is to compare two protocols of intrapartum glucose management in women with GDM and investigate the impact on neonatal blood glucose levels.

detailed_description.textblock:
Research objective- To compare "Tight" vs. "Less Tight" intrapartum glucose management
Hypothesis: Neonates born to mothers managed via the "Less Tight" intrapartum glucose management protocol will have lower mean glucose levels in the first 24 hours of life when compared to mean glucose levels among infants born to mothers managed via the "Tight" intrapartum glucose management protocol.
Study Design: Randomized trial
Population: English or Spanish speaking women with a diagnosis of GDM managed at the Diabetes in Pregnancy Program at Women & Infants Hospital, with a plan to deliver at Women & Infants Hospital
Once enrolled, patients will then be randomized to "Tight" or "Less Tight" intrapartum glucose control.
Once admitted to the labor floor for intrapartum management the appropriate power plan for glucose control will be initiated. The specifics of labor management will be left to the discretion of the provider.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Birth of neonate until time of discharge of neonate to home up to 7 days
secondary_outcome.description: Any admission to Neonatal Intensive Care Unit from moment of birth of neonate until time of discharge of neonate to home

secondary_outcome.measure: Hours in Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Birth of neonate until time of discharge of neonate to home up to 7 days
secondary_outcome.description: Any time spent in Neonatal Intensive Care Unit from moment of birth of neonate until time of discharge of neonate to home

arm_group.description: Intervention Standard Care: Tight glucose control protocol: Goal maternal blood glucose 70-100, q 1 hour blood glucose checks, insulin treatment started with single maternal blood glucose level > 100mg/dL

Intervention: Less Tight glucose control protocol: Goal maternal blood glucose 70-120, q 4 hour blood glucose checks (unless symptomatic), insulin treatment started with single maternal blood glucose > 120 mg/dL

intervention.intervention_name: Standard Protocol for intrapartum glucose management
intervention.description: Tight glucose control protocol: Goal maternal blood glucose 70-100, q 1 hour blood glucose checks, insulin treatment started with single maternal blood glucose level > 100mg/dL

intervention.intervention_name: Experimental Protocol for intrapartum glucose management
intervention.description: Less Tight: Goal maternal blood glucose 70-120, q 4 hour blood glucose checks (unless symptomatic), insulin treatment started with single maternal blood glucose > 120 mg/dL

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- English or Spanish speaking women with a diagnosis of GDM managed at the Diabetes in Pregnancy Program at Women & Infants Hospital, with a plan to deliver at Women & Infants Hospital
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pre-existing DM, multiple gestations, major fetal anomalies anticipated to require NICU admission, planned cesarean delivery, medications known to effect glucose metabolism other than insulin (i.e. metformin)

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island
